Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Inferring Social Organization Through Mortuary Practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The broad and fundamental significance of this research rests on the insight it will provide into how small scale traditional societies are organized. Placed in broader context with other such studies it has the potential to elucidate how social complexity develops and is maintained. Small scale social groupings continue to exist within nation states today and there can be practical benefit to understand how they function.

Does equal treatment in death reflect equal treatment in life? The Iberian Copper Age is a period dominated by the emergence of early complex societies, which are characterized by agricultural intensification, political centralization and population aggregation. Previous research has focused on the phenomenon of collective burial to suggest that these broad-scale social processes are underwritten by a "communally-organized society." However the internal organization of such communities is still poorly understood, particularly because the preservation issues and social function of such collective burials are underexplored.

This research contributes to a growing body of work on the significance of collective burials in prehistory. While this topic has merited increasing anthropological attention in recent years, few Iberian-specific analyses have been conducted that permit researchers to understand what such large-scale sites represent in terms of social organization. Importantly, a better understanding of the communal interments so characteristic of the Iberian Chalcolithic will allow for a more detailed understanding of how these amorphously "collective" early complex societies were actually organized. This project's intellectual merit lies in the fact that its multi-component bioarchaeological and archaeological analysis offers a novel approach to mortuary work in Spain, and should offer a framework for future projects.

At 113 ha in size, Marroqu√≠es Bajos is one of the largest settlements known for the time period, and contains evidence of four different burial programs. This project's bioarchaeological analysis of the mortuary variability at the site will allow for the investigation of the degree to which Iberian Copper Age societies were collectively organized. In particular, it is unclear whether collective burials mask significant differences in individuals' access to food, disease burdens and activity levels as a result of social characteristics like gender, age, or social group affiliation. Through analysis of human remains, isotopic analysis of diet, AMS radiocarbon dating, and an examination of tomb form and grave goods, this research will allow for a more nuanced reconstruction of the ways in which Copper Age societies were organized, while deepening our understanding of how and why collective burials were used by prehistoric populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Relative to the preceding Neolithic period (c. 5600-3200 BC), the Copper Age (c. 3200-2250 BC) in Spain and Portugal is characterized by the emergence of increasing social complexity, including growing populations, agricultural intensification, and the expansion of long-distance exchange networks. The Iberian third millennium BC likewise witnesses the first appearance of “mega-sites” – settlements of a significantly larger spatial extent, or more complex internal infrastructure, than sites documented for earlier periods. However, the form of social organization that underlay the emergence of these new kinds of settlements remains poorly understood. Archaeological investigations of the populations that inhabited these types of settlements thus have the potential to resolve questions concerning the emergence of social complexity in human societies. 

To address these questions, Jess Beck conducted a bioarchaeological analysis of human skeletal remains from three necropolises – Necropolis 1 (N1), Necropolis 2 (N2), and Necropolis 4 (N4) – at the mega-site of Marroquíes Bajos (Jaén, Spain). At 113 ha, Marroquíes Bajos is one of the largest villages known for the Iberian Copper Age, and contains evidence for significant investment of communal labor in site architecture, including a series of concentric ditches expanding outwards from the center of the site, portions of an adobe wall accompanying the fourth ditch, and extensive traces of domestic architecture. At least four spatially segregated mortuary tracks are also present at this site, including (1) individual secondary burials in discrete mortuary structures; (2) individual primary burials in discrete mortuary structures; (3) collective secondary deposits in pits, and (4) collective and individual burials in a series of artificial caves located outside of the enclosure system. The aim of this project was to investigate whether Marroquíes Bajos showed evidence of collective social organization, or whether there were significant disparities in health, diet or material culture among the social units being represented in these burials. To answer this question, Beck drew upon multiple lines of evidence, including bioarchaeological analysis of human skeletal remains, isotopic analysis of diet (carbon, nitrogen) and mobility (strontium, oxygen), AMS radiocarbon dating, and archaeological analysis of tomb form and grave goods.

The results of Beck’s bioarchaeological analysis revealed that N1, N2, and N4 contained at least 280 individuals (201 adults; 79 subadults). Individuals of both sexes and almost all ages were interred in all three necropolises. Strontium and oxygen isotopic analyses were conducted for a sample of 115 individuals, and nine non-local individuals were identified. Isotopic analyses of of mobility showed that mortuary practices were inclusive in regards to regional origin – in death non-local individuals were accorded the same mortuary treatments as locals, and buried together with locals. Carbon and nitrogen isotope results of the 89 human mandibles from N1 and N4 that preserved sufficient collagen for analysis revealed that human diets were largely composed of C3 plants and terrestrial protein, with no significant differences in diet between the two mortuary areas. Levels of paleopathology were low for all mortuary areas, with caries, enamel hypoplasias, and calculus the most frequently represented pathologies. There were no significant differences in caries or calculus between mortuary areas, though there were significant differences in the frequency of hypoplasias, with higher levels occurring at N2 than at N1 or N4.

AMS radiocarbon dates taken from 34 human bones show that N1 and N4 date to the mid-third millennium. In contrast, N2 shows a period of reuse during the Early Bronze Age, and changes in diet during this later period may explain the differences in signs of nutritional stress (i.e. hypoplasias) between the mortuary areas.

Almost all mortuary structures from N1, N2, and N4 contain some form of communal interment, whether burials are primary, secondary, or commingled cave depositions. Broad similarities in demography and grave goods link these mortuary areas, suggesting that funerary rituals acted as a common thread tying the inhabitants of the site together. However, the distinct spatial location of each area, along with differences in funerary treatment also underscore the maintenance of mortuary practices specific to particular social units. Taken together, these results suggest that marked increases in inequality were not necessary to found the large villages that appeared for the first time in the third millennium BC, and that collective burials may have been used as a means of creating and reinforcing community identities that allowed for the emergence of these kinds of centers.

As doctoral dissertation research, the broader outcomes of this project included providing essential training for the doctoral candidate in implementing and carrying out research of her own design. This project also entailed the study of salvage-excavated museum collections, facilitating the analysis of human skeletal remains that would otherwise remain unstudied, in order to develop a synthetic model of social organization at one of the earliest large-scale villages in Iberia.
